title: Settling Debts: Is it true that you should never give them your bank account number or debit card number?
question: My credit cards are all in collections & I'm in the process of reaching an agreement with them. But I'm confused as to how to send them payment.
answers: I usually tell the client to send cashiers check or money order especially if it is a lump sum settlement.

First of all, get the terms of the agreement in writing. Include their obligation to remove the negative information from your credit reports. It can be a "Delete tradeline" if the collector uses a Universal Data form. If it was reported by the original creditor and not the assignee (collection agency), get both to sign the agreement.

After there is a signed agreement, pay with a bank check or cashiers check. Do not give them your bank account information.

Generally, debt collectors will use all means necessary under the law to collect a debt. This can include garnishing your wages, levying your bank accounts, etc. The more information you provide, the more ways that have to collect from you. Your post stated that you are in the process of settling the debt. Do you have a written settlement agreement? Is there already a court judgment against you for the full amount? If there is already a court judgment, the creditor can call you in for a Judgment Debtor’s Examination to aid in the collections efforts. You would be required to provide them with your bank account information at the JDX if they requested it. If there is a judgment in place, the creditor can also obtain a Writ of Execution. This document would be given to the sheriff’s department in your county and the sheriff’s department could serve your bank with the Writ of Execution. In essence, they could take money from your bank accounts directly. Please keep in mind that in most counties/states creditors do not need your bank account number to place a levy on your bank account. Simply the name and address of your bank will do.

You might wish to consider asking for a written settlement agreement that can be reviewed by an attorney. If there is a judgment in place, you will want to make sure that once the funds are paid, the judgment is removed. Because collections cases can become very complicated, I would suggest finding a collections attorney in your area who can walk you through the process.
I always suggest using official checks issued by your bank. Also make sure you get the terms of the offer in writing.
